title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States provide care for family members with chronic illnesses or disabilities, including children with special needs and those living with relatives due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. Approximately 6,000,000 children in the United States live with a grandparent or relative due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. An estimated 165,000 children with disabilities live with foster care parents, while nearly 4,000,000 individuals with mental retardation or developmental disabilities live with their families. Additionally, almost 25% of the Nation's elders rely on others for help due to multiple chronic disabling conditions. Approximately 25% of the Nation's elders have multiple chronic disabling conditions, requiring assistance with daily living. Around 600,000 Americans die at home each year, relying on extensive family caregiving. 42% of individuals in the US needing daily assistance are under 65, and there are insufficient resources to replace family caregivers with paid workers, which would cost $200 billion annually. Approximately 75% of family caregivers are women, facing emotional, physical, and financial hardships. They often struggle to find information on available respite care, which is insufficient and mainly targets lower-income individuals. If family caregivers were replaced with paid services, it would cost around $200 billion annually. The current chunk highlights the insufficiency of available respite care programs, primarily targeting lower-income populations and family caregivers of the elderly. There is a limited number of programs that struggle to recruit trained respite workers. The purposes of this title are to encourage the establishment of State and local lifespan respite care programs and improve dissemination coordination. The purposes of this title are to encourage States to establish respite care programs, improve dissemination of information to family caregivers, provide respite care services, and promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery and training programs. The purposes of this title include supporting respite care worker and volunteer recruitment, training programs for family caregivers, evaluative research on effective respite care services, and dissemination of results and findings related to respite care delivery and caregiver strain. The curr_chunk focuses on programs and research projects related to respite care delivery, family caregiver strain, worker and volunteer recruitment and training, and training programs for family caregivers. The curr_chunk focuses on defining key terms related to respite care delivery, family caregiver strain, worker and volunteer recruitment and training, and training programs for family caregivers. The curr_chunk defines the term 'condition' to include various health and developmental issues such as Alzheimer's disease, physical disabilities, chronic illness, and situations of abuse or neglect. The curr_chunk outlines situations that pose a high risk of abuse or neglect, parental unavailability due to death or incapacity, traumatic brain injury, and other conditions designated by the Secretary. Eligible recipients include State agencies and other capable public entities. Eligible recipients include State agencies, public entities operating statewide, private nonprofit organizations operating statewide, political subdivisions with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, and recognized State respite coordinating agencies with demonstrated abilities. Recognized State respite coordinating agencies must have the ability to collaborate with other agencies, understand respite care and caregiver issues, and involve family members, caregivers, and care recipients. The term 'family caregiver' refers to an unpaid family member or adult providing in-home care for a child or adult with special needs. 'Lifespan respite care' is a system of community-based services for family caregivers regardless of age or special needs. 'Respite care' is planned temporary care for caregivers. The term 'respite care' refers to planned or emergency care provided to individuals with special needs to give temporary relief to family caregivers or when the caregiver is unable to provide care. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. 'Special need' refers to the particular needs of individuals of any age requiring care. The term 'special need' refers to the particular needs of individuals of any age who require care or supervision due to a condition to meet their basic needs or prevent harm. "SEC. 2803. LIFESPAN RESPITE CARE GRANTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS." The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose. The Secretary can award grants to eligible recipients who submit an application for respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs of all ages. Coordination with various agencies is required to ensure the Federal Lifespan Approach. The Health Services Administration coordinates respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Eligible recipients must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant or cooperative agreement, including a description of their understanding of respite care. The applicant's description should include their understanding of respite care, capacity for involving family members, caregivers, and care recipients, and collaboration with other agencies. The applicant should provide a description of the population of family caregivers who will receive respite care information or services, including their needs and existing services available to them. The applicant should describe the population of family caregivers, including numbers served and unmet needs, existing methods to coordinate respite care information, services at State and local levels, and extent of unmet need. The applicant should provide respite care services, training programs for caregivers, and collaboration plans with other related services using grant funds. The applicant should coordinate respite care activities with other services and involve the population in planning and implementation. The applicant should ensure respite care activities maximize use of available funds, programs, and facilities, improving services for family caregivers in the State or locality. The applicant's plan for use of funds will improve the coordination and distribution of respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Criteria for identifying eligible family caregivers and monitoring the quality and safety of respite care services will be included. The respite care services provided will be monitored to ensure workers and volunteers are screened and possess necessary skills. Expected results from respite care activities and evaluation procedures will be included. Assurances will be given where appropriate. The Secretary will establish a panel to review applications for respite care services, which will meet as needed to expedite the process. The panel's function is to evaluate applications and ensure confidentiality of care recipient and family caregiver records. The panel will meet as necessary to review and evaluate applications for respite care services, making recommendations to the Secretary for approval. The Secretary will award grants or cooperative agreements based on the panel's recommendations. The Secretary awards grants or cooperative agreements based on panel recommendations, giving priority to applicants focusing on lifespan respite care statewide. Grant funds must be used as agreed upon. The Secretary awards grants or cooperative agreements to eligible recipients for the development of lifespan respite care at the State and local levels, providing respite care services, and evaluating the effectiveness of such services. Each recipient must agree to use the funds as specified. The Secretary awards grants or cooperative agreements for the development of lifespan respite care, providing services, and evaluating effectiveness. Recipients can subcontract with public or nonprofit agencies. Grants are awarded for terms up to 5 years and can be renewed. The Secretary may renew grants for respite care services for up to 5 years. Funds must supplement, not supplant, other available federal, state, and local funds. The Secretary will award a grant to establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care. The Center will maintain a national database, provide training and assistance to respite care programs, and offer information and educational programs to the public. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the establishment of a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care.
